1.0 	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM-BACKGROUND
The Accidental Release Prevention (ARP) requirements mandated in Section 112 (r) of the 1990 Clean Air Act (CAA) Amendments were promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) on June 20, 1996. The requirements are codified in 40 CFR 68, Subparts A  H. Under the ARP Program, a Stationary Source that has more than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance in a process must comply with the requirements of the ARP provisions.
The List Rule (under 40 CFR 68, Subpart C, and Tables 1 through 4 of 68.130) identifies regulated substance threshold quantities for determining ARP Program applicability. Threshold quantities have been established for flammable and toxic substances. The threshold quantity for all regulated flammables (Table 3 of the regulation) is 10,000 pounds. The threshold determination for mixtures of flammable substances is in accordance with 40 CFR 68.115(b) (2). In cases where the listed substance is greater than one percent by weight of the mixture (for a flammable),

the entire weight of the mixture is considered in the threshold determination, unless it can be demonstrated that the mixture itself does not have a National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) flammability hazard rating of 4. The threshold quantity for regulated toxic substances listed on Table 1 of the regulation varies according to each substance and ranges from 500  20,000 pounds.
Each covered process regulated under the ARP Program is assigned as either a Program 1, 2, or 3 status and must meet the applicable criteria of the assigned program. Program 1 processes are those that meet the following criteria:
·	the process has not had an accidental release in the past five years that resulted in an offsite consequence (i.e., injuries, deaths, or environmental damage);
·	the distance to an endpoint is less than the distance to any public receptor; and
·	Emergency response has been coordinated with local emergency response organizations.
Program 3 processes meet the following criteria:
·	the distance to an endpoint exceeds the distance to any public receptor; or
·	the process has had an accidental release in the past five years resulting in an offsite consequence; and either.
·	Falls into one of ten NAICS codes [32211, 31411, 32511, 325181, 325188, 325192, 325199, 325211, 325311, and 32532]; or subject to the OSHA process safety management standard [40 CFR 68.10 (d) (2)].
Program 2 processes are those that do not meet Program 1 or 3 criteria.
2.0		Stationary Source ARP Program Status Determination
	2.1.	Background
Energy Transfer Gulf Coast Operations is the owner/operator of the Stationary Source, Olefin grade (NGL) cryogenic unit, located at a latitude 29° 55' 54.22" N and longitude 89° 57' 55.15" W in Saint Bernard Parish, Louisiana. 

The primary function of the Stationary Source is mechanically removing through cryogenics means the regulated substances (NGLs) from the waste gas stream from the oil refinery, then returning the methane and butane to the refinery

. All other Olefin products, Ethylene, Propylene, Ethane, and Butane are recovered and sent out by pipeline.  

By virtue of the flammable effects associated with NGLs, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community. 

2.2		Hazard Assessment
The Stationary Source was evaluated to determine if any regulated flammable or toxic substances were present in the process and if they exceeded the threshold quantity. All equipment and vessels are connected and/or co-located; consequently, for the purposes of the ARP Program, all equipment and vessels are part of multiple processes. The identification of even a single vessel exceeding threshold quantities of a regulated flammable or toxic substance would subject a process to threshold determination for offsite consequence analysis.
There are no regulated toxic substances at this Stationary Source more than RMP threshold quantities.
This Stationary Source does store regulated flammable substances in vessels that exceed threshold quantity; therefore, the Stationary Source is a covered process with regulated substances subject to threshold determination for offsite consequence analysis (see Table 1). 3.0	OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS-BACKGROUND
Under the accidental release provisions of the CAA, regulated sources with covered processes are required to complete an offsite consequence analysis, including a worst-case release analysis. Regulated sources with covered processes in Programs 2 and 3 are required to conduct alternative release analyses as well. The worst-case consequence analysis and the analysis for alternative scenarios are to be reported in the Risk Management Plan (RMP).
      3.1	Worst-Case Scenario (WCS)
The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has defined a worst-case release as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to a specified endpoint. A WCS analysis is required for eac

h toxic substance in a covered process while only one WCS analysis is required for regulated flammable substances as a class. WCSs are assumed to occur at ground level with meteorological conditions defined as atmospheric stability class F (stable atmosphere), wind speed of 1.5 meter per second (3.4 miles per hour), and an ambient air temperature of 25oC (77oF). Topography for WCSs is either rural or urban depending on site location.
The basis for determining the WCS for flammable liquids are as follows:
   (1)	For regulated flammable substances that are normally liquids at ambient temperature, the owner or operator shall assume that the entire quantity in the vessel or pipe, is spilled instantaneously to form a liquid pool. 
For liquids at temperatures below their atmospheric boiling point, the owner or operator shall assume that the entire quantity in the vessel or pipe, is spilled instantaneously to form a liquid pool.
    (2)	The owner or operator shall assume that the quantity which becomes vapor in the first 10 minutes is involved in the vapor cloud explosion.

Factors in selecting a worst-case scenario. 
   (1)	Smaller quantities handled at higher process temperature or pressure; 
   (2)	Proximity to the boundary of the stationary source. 
   (3)	Worst-case scenario methodologies are illustrated in Worst Case Scenario Modeling Assumptions considered, extent of 1 PSIG and Receptors.

Flammable Substances
Regulated flammable substances or mixtures containing flammable substances include both gas and volatile liquids (flash point below 73oF, boiling point below 100oF). The WCS assumes that the total quantity of a vapor cloud is released and detonates. The endpoint for a WCS involving a regulated flammable substance or mixture is an over pressure of 1 pound per square inch (psi). For a regulated flammable substance, consequence distance determination is based on its heat of combustion. For regulated flammable mixtures, the component with the highest heat of co

mbustion can be used for consequence distance determination or, if preferred, directly calculated using RMP Comp calculator on the EPA website. The quantity of a regulated substance/mixture used to determine distance to endpoint is the largest quantity of a regulated substance/mixture in a single vessel.
      3.1.1	Stationary Source Worst-Case Scenario for Regulated Flammables
The Stationary Source can store NFPA 4 Regulated Liquids in multiple vessels inside the boundary.  It was determined that the 15,910 gallons/69,010lbs. 3.1.2	Stationary Source Worst Case Scenario for Regulated Toxics

The Stationary Source does not have any toxic substances held above the threshold quantity. Analysis of one worst-case release scenario for all regulated toxic substances is therefore, not required.

3.2      Alternative Release Scenario (ARS)

An ARS describes an incident that is more likely to occur than those cited for a WCS. One ARS analysis is required for each l

isted toxic substance in a covered process that exceeds threshold quantity while only one ARS analysis is required for all flammable substances as a class. For ARSs, both active and passive mitigation systems can be considered, however for this study no mitigation was used.
Alternative release scenarios for flammable substances should have the potential to cause substantial damage, including on-site damage. Alternative release scenarios for toxic substances should be those that lead to concentrations above the toxic endpoint beyond the process fence line. Those releases that have the potential to reach the public are of the greatest concern.

3.2.1    Stationary Source Alternative Release Scenario for Regulated Flammables

Four (4) separate alternative release scenarios were modeled for various quadrants of the Stationary Source and differing volumes. These scenarios were also modeled per the requirements of Subpart B §68.28 (b) (2).
It was determined that a release from a ruptured transfer hose at 8,010 pound per minute rate would be the primary alternative release scenario. Using RMP*Comp it was determined that a release of this amount of liquid would result in a vapor cloud fire with an endpoint (LFL) distance of 0.10 miles. 4.0	ACCIDENT HISTORY
According to 40 CFR 68.42, The owner or operator shall include in the five-year accident. 
history all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.
The Stationary Source has not had any accidental releases during the past five years that meet the criteria for an accidental release as discussed in 40 CFR 68.42.

5.0	VERIFICATION OF PROCESS INFORMATION
Facilities have an ongoing responsibility to monitor whether changes to any process or to the quantities stored or handled alter the Stationary Sources program level eligibility. A 5-year renewal also gives the Stationary Source personnel the opportunity to verify that each covered process still meets the eligibility criteria for its program level. Based on information regarding the type and quantity of stored/handled chemicals currently onsite, it was verified that the Stationary Source process areas are Program 3 processes under the ARP Program (40 CFR 68).

6.0 	REVIEW OF EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The Stationary Source is not designated as a first responder in case of an accidental release of a regulated substance. The Stationary Source maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidently released. If Stat

ionary Source employees take part in responding to accidental releases, then the Stationary Source is required to periodically review and update, as appropriate, the Stationary Sources emergency response program and notify employees of any changes to the emergency response plan (40 CFR 68.95). Updates should include the date of the most recent review of the emergency response program and most recent training. The Stationary Source is also expected to contact the Local Emergency Planning Committee to verify whether the Stationary Source is currently included in the community emergency response plan. Section 9 of the CDX RMP Submit Document (Appendix 4) provides updated information (including dates and other pertinent details) that was reviewed by the Stationary Source to ensure that the procedures for the emergency response program have been updated and verified.


7.0	GENERAL DUTY CLAUSE
Owners and operators of facilities have a general duty to identify hazards that may result from accidental releases of any flammable or toxic substance at the Stationary Source. In addition, owners and operators are required to design and maintain a safe Stationary Source and minimize the consequences of any releases of these substances that occur.
